CatDescriptText: Mrs. Marceal Scott, housewife, Fifth Ward and Mrs. Joliver Williams, receptionist, Homewood, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column, published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, September 16, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think that political party policy makers respect the Negro vote and act accordingly, or do they take it for granted?  Why?" Mrs. Scott's answer reads: "They consider our vote important, because we are taxpayers and a great many of us are homeowners."  Mrs. Williams' answer reads: "There are policymakers [sic] who do, because Negroes have done so much and proved worthy.  However, they don't show as much respect as they should and I think that is because that once they are in power they tend to forget those persons who put them into power."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Marceal Scott wearing eyeglasses and dark short sleeve shirt with cross bands and buttons, standing on sidewalk in front of buildings; Portrait of Joliver Williams wearing checkered coat with rounded collar, standing in front of tree, car and buildings in background
